metadata.title: Laminar forced convection performance of non-Newtonian water-CNT/Fe3O4 nano-fluid inside a minichannel hairpin heat exchanger: Effect of inlet temperature

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Powder Technology
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /powtec
Laminar forced convection performance of non-Newtonian water-CNT/ Fe3O4 nano-fluid inside a minichannel hairpin heat exchanger: Effect of inlet temperature
W.I. Liu a,b, Abdullah A.A.A. Al-Rashed c, Ali Sulaiman Alsagri d, Boshra Mahmoudi e, Amin Shahsavar f, Masoud Afrand g,h,⁎ a School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou 221116, China b Jiangsu Collaborative Innovation Center of Intelligent Mining Equipment, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou 221116, China c Department of Automotive and Marine Engineering Technology, College of Technological Studies, The Public Authority for Applied Education and Training, Kuwait d Mechanical Engineering Department, Unayzah College of Engineering, Qassim University, Qassim 51911, Saudi Arabia e Research Center, Sulaimani Polytechnic University, Sulaimani 46001, Kurdistan Region, Iraq f Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kermanshah University of Technology, Kermanshah, Iran g Laboratory of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials, Advanced Institute of Materials Science, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam h Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
⁎ Corresponding author at: Ton Duc Thang University, E-mail addresses: a.alsagri@qu.edu.sa (A.S. Alsagri), Bo
(B. Mahmoudi), a.shahsavar@kut.ac.ir (A. Shahsavar), ma (M. Afrand).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.powtec.2019.05.079 0032-5910/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 3 February 2019 Received in revised form 17 May 2019 Accepted 30 May 2019 Available online 04 June 2019
This numerical study aims to focus on the effect of difference between the inlet temperatures ofworking fluids on the hydrothermal characteristics of a counter-current minichannel hairpin heat exchanger. The water flows in the annulus side and the water based hybrid nano-fluid containing Fe3O4 and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) passes through the tube side of heat exchanger. Temperature-dependent thermal conductivity and viscosity are considered for the non-Newtonian hybrid nano-fluid. The effects of Fe3O4 and CNT volume fractions aswell as the Reynolds number on the performance metrics of the heat exchanger are also assessed. The results revealed that the increase of difference between the inlet temperatures ofworkingfluids leads to the augmentation of heat transfer rate, overall heat transfer coefficient (except at Reynolds number of 500), heat exchanger effectiveness and PEC; while the pumping power diminishes with the increase of inlet water temperature.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. Keywords: Hybrid nano-fluid Hairpin heat exchanger Heat transfer Inlet temperature Carbon nanotube Fe3O4

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, news on the advances made in nanotechnology and its new applications has been released every day. Nanotechnology has opened up new panoramas for applications in various areas including medicine, electronics, food, fuel cells, space, fuels, and chemical sensors. It is expected that nanotechnology will change human life more profoundly than many developments of the past.
One of the areas that benefits from the use of nanotechnology is heat transfer. Nano-fluids are modern heat transfer fluids, prepared by dispersing and stably suspending nanoadditives of size 1–100 nm within common heat transfer liquids. Studies have revealed that these new fluids exhibit better heat transfer properties than the base fluids [1–7].
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. shra.mahmoudi@spu.edu.iq soud.afrand@tdtu.edu.vn
Consequently, they have attracted a great deal of interest of researchers around the world. Considerable efforts have been devoted to studying the thermophysical properties of nano-fluids [8–11] aswell as the application of nano-fluids in diversefields, such as solar energy [12–14], electronic cooling [15–17], and engine cooling [18–20].
Heat exchangers are devices that are widely used in various industries. In this equipment, heat is exchanged between two or more fluids. In recent years, several experimental and numerical investigations have been performed on the performance of nano-fluids through the heat exchangers. Goodarzi et al. [21] performed a numerical assessment to examine the hydrothermal behavior of nitrogen-doped graphene nano-fluid through a hairpin heat exchanger. They reported a maximum heat transfer augmentation of 16.2% through using the nanofluid. Bahiraei et al. [22] conducted simulations to evaluate the irreversibility of water-CNT/Fe3O4 nano-fluid flow through a minichannel hairpin heat exchanger. The outcomes revealed that the heat transfer and flow friction are the main source of irreversibility at low and high volume fractions of nanoadditives. Shahsavar et al. [23] numerically studied the hydrothermal characteristics and irreversibility behaviour of
Nomenclature
cp Specific heat capacity (J/kg.K) d Diameter (m) dout Outlet diameter (m) k Thermal conductivity (W/m.K) _m Mass flow rate (kg/s) p Pressure (Pa) _Q Real heat transfer rate (W) _Qmax Maximum heat transfer rate (W) Re Reynolds number T Temperature (KK) U Overall heat transfer coefficient (W/m2.K) V Velocity (m/s) _V Volumetric flow rate (m3/s) _Wpump Pumping power (WK)
Greek symbols ε Effectiveness φ Concentration (%) η Performance index (W/Pa) μ Viscosity (kg/m.s) ρ Density (kg/m3) γ Shear rate (1/s)
Subscripts CNT Carbon nanotube in Inlet M Magnetic nanoparticle nf Nanofluid out Outlet w Water
the non-Newtonian water-CNT/Fe3O4 nano-fluid flow inside a hairpin heat exchanger. The thermal conductivity and viscosity of the studied nano-fluid were temperature-dependent. It was reported that both the overall hat transfer coefficient and total irreversibility go up with boosting either Reynolds number or nanoadditive volume fraction. Karimi and Afrand [24] conducted simulations to examine the impacts of water-MgO/CNT nano-fluid on the working parameters of an air-cooled heat exchanger. They also assessed and compared the performance of horizontal and vertical heat exchangers. It was
Fig. 1. Schematic o
reported that the vertical heat exchanger has a superior efficiency in comparison with the horizontal one. Diglio et al. [25] examined the working parameters of a borehole heat exchanger filled with aqueous nano-fluids containing Ag, Cu, Al, Al2O3, CuO, Graphite and SiO2 nanoadditives. Among the studied nano-fluids, the water-Cu nanofluid showed the maximum borehole thermal resistance reduction. Rahimi et al. [26] implemented the lattice-Boltzmann method to analyze the natural convection flow of water-CuO nano-fluid through a hollow heat exchanger using different types of nanoadditives. The outcomes revealed that the nano-fluid with platelet type nanoadditives represents the best performance.
From the literature survey, it is seen that there is no comprehensive study on the impact of inlet temperature on the working parameters of a hairpin heat exchanger filled with nano-fluids. The present work is carried out to bridge this research gap. To this end, hydrothermal aspects of a counter-current hairpin heat exchanger filled with waterCNT/Fe3O4 nano-fluid are evaluated considering various nano-fluid inlet temperatures. Besides, the impacts of Reynolds number as well as the volume fractions of CNT and Fe3O4 nanoadditives are also examined.

sections.heading: 2.1. Physical model
sections.text:
Schematic sketch of the considered hairpin heat exchanger is presented in Fig. 1. It is seen that the nano-fluid flows through the tube side (din = 1 mm) and the water flows counter currently through the annulus side (dout = 2 mm) of the heat exchanger with length of L = 1 m. According to axial symmetric, the problem is modeled twodimensionally according to Fig. 1 with symmetrical axial boundary in thebottom. In order to derive the governing equations, the following assumptions are considered: (i) both working fluids are incompressible; (ii) the flow is laminar and steady; (iii) the effect of gravity is negligible; and (iv) the thickness of solid walls are zero.
f the problem.
The governing equations of steady state forced convective laminar flow are continuity, momentum and energy equations which are as follows [22,23]:
Continuity equation:
∇: ρVð Þ ¼ 0 ð1Þ
Momentum equation:
∇: ρVVð Þ ¼ −∇pþ ∇: μ∇Vð Þ ð2Þ
for the computational domain.
Energy equation:
∇: ρVcpT ¼ ∇: k∇Tð Þ ð3Þ In the above equations, ρ, μ, k and cp are respectively density, viscosity, thermal conductivity, and specific heat. In addition,V is velocity vector, p is pressure and T is temperature.

sections.heading: 2.3. Boundary conditions
sections.text:
Both the nano-fluid and water enter the heat exchanger with uniform velocity and temperature. At the outlets, the zero relative pressure condition is employed. The no slip condition is also imposed on the walls, and an adiabatic thermal condition is utilized on the outer wall.
Mathematically all the boundary conditions are represented as follows:
Flow inlet:
u!¼ u!in; T ¼ Tin ð4aÞ
Flow outlet:
p ¼ p0 ð4bÞ
At the solid-fluid internal interface:
u!¼ 0;−knf ∂T ∂n ¼ q00 ð4cÞ
At the outer wall:
u!¼ 0; ∂T ∂n ¼ 0 ð4dÞ

sections.heading: 2.4. Governing equations for computing thermophysical aspects of nanofluid and performance parameters
sections.text:
In this numerical assessment, the considered nano-fluid is the aqueous suspension of Fe3O4 coated CNTs. The details of the preparation and characterization of this hybrid nano-fluid can be found in the author's previouswork [27–30]. Briefly, the nano-fluid is prepared bymixing required amount of water-Fe3O4 and water-CNT nano-fluids, followed by mixture sonication for 5 min.
The volume fraction of the Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives in the studied nano-fluid samples as well as the density and specific heat of these hybrid nano-fluids are presented in Table 1.
The findings revealed that the water-CNT/Fe3O4 hybrid nanofluid exhibits pseudoplastic behavior and its viscosity reduces by boosting the shear rate until it reaches a plateau at shear rates higher than 70 s−1 [9]. In addition, as the temperature of nanofluid intensifies, the viscosity of the hybrid nano-fluid reduces [9]. Moreover, the results showed that the thermal conductivity of the hybrid nano-fluid intensifies by boosting the temperature and nanoadditive volume fraction [9]. Using the experimental data, the artificial neural network was utilized to obtain appropriate correlations for viscosity and thermal conductivity of the water-CNT/Fe3O4 hybrid nano-fluid in terms of temperature, volume fraction of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives, and shear rate (for viscosity) [31,32]. The obtained neural network models show a significant accuracy to predict the thermal conductivity and viscosity according to Fig. 2. The correlations developed are presented in appendix A, and it is clear that the models are temperate dependent.
The Reynolds number of nano-fluid (Renf) and water (Rew) can be calculated as:
Renf ¼ ρnf uin;nf din
μnf ð5Þ
Rew ¼ ρwuin;w dout−dinð Þμw ð6Þ
where uin, nf is the nano-fluid inlet velocity and uin, wis the water inlet velocity. It should be noted that the considered nano-fluid viscosity for calculating the Reynolds number is equal to the viscosity at shear rates higher than 70 s−1.
The efficiency of heart exchanger is computed as [33]:
ε ¼ _Q
_Qmax ð7Þ
where _Q is the real heat transfer ate and _Qmax is the maximum possible heat transfer rate through the heat exchanger. These parameters are calculated as:
_Q ¼ _mnf cp;nf Tin;nf−Tout;nf ¼ _mwcp;w Tout;w−Tin;w ð8Þ
_Qmax ¼ _mcp min Tin;nf−Tin;w ð9Þ
Since the steady state flow in a heat exchanger with an adiabatic external wall has been considered, therefore, the heat transfer between the flowing fluids are equal.
The total heat transfer coefficient is obtained as [33]:
U ¼ _Q
πLdin ln Tout;w−Tin;nf − Tin;w−Tout;nf
Tout;w−Tin;nf = Tin;w−Tout;nf
( ) ð10Þ
The required pumping power to circulate nano-fluid through the heat exchanger is computed as [33]:
_Wpump ¼ _VΔp ð11Þ
where _V and Δp are respectively the volumetric flow rate and pressure loss of nano-fluid in the heat exchanger.
When providing a method to increase the heat transfer in heat exchangers, the pressure loss (or pumping power) should not be ignored. Increasing the heat transfer should not be accompanied by a high pressure loss. For this purpose, a parameter called performance index is employed, which shows the ratio of heat transfer rate to pressure loss, as [33]:
η ¼ _Q Δp
ð12Þ
2.5. Numerical method and validation
The governing Eqs. (1)–(3) and the associated boundary conditions are solved numerically by the control volume approach. The second order upwind approach is utilized for solving the equations of
momentumand energy, whereas the SIMPLEmethod is adopted to couple velocity and pressure. For all parameters, the convergence criteria is set to 10−6.
Grid quality is one of the issues that greatly affects the accuracy of numerical solution. Hence, the grid independent test is essential to determine the most appropriate grid for performing the required simulations. In this study, as shown in Fig. 3, a structured mesh based on a rectangular grid is adopted throughout the domain. Local grid refinement is applied near the walls, where the highest velocity and temperature gradients occur. The grid independence is checked by comparing the performance of five different grid systems in obtaining the heat transfer rate and pressure drop of 0.9%FF + 1.35%CNT hybrid nano-fluid at Renf = 2000, Rew = 1000, Tin, nf = 298 K and Tin, w = 308 K. The outcomes are presented in Table 2. Finally, the grid with 45 nodes radially for both the tube side and annulus side of the heat exchanger, and 1000 nodes in longitudinal direction was selected as the best one.
The validation of the numerical method is carried out with the study done by Duangthongsuk and Wongwises [34]. They assessed experimentally the forced convection flow of water-TiO2 nanofluid in a hairpin heat exchanger. Table 3 shows the results of this comparison for the variations of Nusselt number with Reynolds number. The comparison shows a good agreement between the present results with the findings of Duangthongsuk and Wongwises [34].

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In this study, the impacts of inlet temperature on the hydrothermal aspects of a counter-current hairpin heat exchanger containing waterCNT/Fe3O4 nano-fluid are evaluated. The numerical simulations are conducted at Fe3O4 volume fractions of 0 to 0.9%, CNT volume fractions of 0–1.35%, nano-fluid Reynolds numbers of 500–2000, nano-fluid inlet temperatures of 298 K, water inlet temperature of 308–338 K, and water Reynolds number of 500–2000.
The effects of inlet water temperature on the nano-fluid temperature profile at tube cross sections x = 0.1 m, x = 0.5 m and x = 0.9 m have been displayed in Fig. 4. It is observed that the rise of inlet water temperature leads to the increase of nanofluid temperature at different cross sections, and that the amount of temperature rise near the tube wall is greater than that in the central regions of tube. It is also observed that at each cross section, the amount of nano-fluid temperature rise goes up with the
increase of inlet water temperature; which is due to the further increase of nano-fluid's thermal conductivity in these cases. It should be mentioned that at a constant nanoadditive volume fraction, the thermal conductivity coefficient of the nano-fluid is only a function of its temperature and, therefore, the pattern of variations of thermal conductivity coefficient is similar to that of the nano-fluid temperature and so it is not included in this work.
(b)

Fig. 11. PEC versus nanoadditive volume fraction at various inlet water temperatures for Rew = 1000 and (a) Renf = 500 and φM = 0.9%, (b) Renf = 2000 and φM = 0.9%, (c) Renf = 500 and φCNT = 1.35% and (a) Renf = 2000 and φCNT = 1.35%.
The changes of nano-fluid viscosity with inlet water temperature at tube cross sections x= 0.1 m, x= 0.5 m and x= 0.9 m have been presented in Fig. 5. It is observed that at all the considered cross sections, thenano-fluid viscosity diminisheswith rise of inletwater temperature; which is due to the increase of nano-fluid temperature. It is also revealed that the viscosity of nano-fluid near the tube wall is less than that in the central tube region; which is due to the higher values of velocity gradient near the tube wall.
Fig. 6 depicts the changes of nano-fluid velocity with inlet water temperature at tube cross sections x = 0.1 m, x = 0.5 m and x = 0.9 m. It is seen that at all the considered cross sections, as the temperature rises from 308 to 338 K, the velocity decreases in the central region of tube and increases in the vicinity of wall, which is due to the decrease of viscosity near the wall.
Fig. 7 gives the changes of heat transfer ratewith inletwater temperature at various volume fractions of Fe3O4 and CNT and various Reynolds numbers. It is observed that the rise of inlet water temperature results in the augmentation of heat transfer rate; which, according to Eq. (8), is due to the increase of nano-fluid outlet temperature. Fig. 7 also shows the increase of heat transfer rate with boosting the nanoadditive volume fraction and Reynolds number. The increase of nanoadditive volume fraction leads to the simultaneous increase of nano-fluid density and viscosity; however, the increase of viscosity is greater and, consequently, the average velocity of nano-fluid should be increased in order to keep the Reynolds number fixed. Also, the augmentation of Reynolds number at a constant nanoadditive volume fraction leads to the increase of nano-fluid velocity and thus the increase of heat transfer rate.
Fig. 8 displays the effects of inlet water temperature on overall heat transfer coefficient at various volume fractions of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives and different Reynolds numbers. This figure shows that at different CNT volume fractions, the rise of inlet water temperature leads to the increase of overall heat transfer coefficient. This trend is also seen at different volume fractions of Fe3O4 nanoadditives and at Reynolds number of 2000; while at the Reynolds of 500, the pattern of the changes of overall heat transfer coefficient with inlet water temperature is quite different. Fig. 8 also shows that at the Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.9%, the overall heat transfer coefficient increases with the increase of Reynolds number and CNT volume fraction; while at a constant CNT volume fraction, the changes of the overall heat transfer coefficient with Reynolds number and Fe3O4 volume fraction do not follow a fixed and regular trend. For example, at Reynolds number of 500, the maximum overall heat transfer coefficient is obtained
at Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.5% and inlet water temperature of 338 K; while at Reynolds number of 2000, the highest overall heat transfer coefficient is achieved at Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.9% and inlet water temperature of 338 K.
Fig. 9 illustrates the effects of inlet water temperature on the heat exchanger effectiveness at various volume fractions of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives and at Reynolds numbers of 500 and
2000. The findings depict that the heat exchanger effectiveness improves with the increase of inlet water temperature. For example, at Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.9% and CNT volume fraction of 1.35%, by raising the inlet water temperature from 308 to 338 K, the heat exchanger effectiveness goes up by 1.17% and 0.39% at Reynolds numbers of 500 and 2000, respectively. It is also observed that the augmentation of Reynolds number causes the reduction of heat exchanger effectiveness; while the increase of Fe3O4 volume fraction from zero to 0.1% leads to the increase and the further increase of Fe3O4 volume fraction leads to the decrease of effectiveness. It is also observed that the increase of CNT volume fraction reduces the heat exchanger effectiveness at Reynolds number of 500 and increases it at Reynolds number of 2000.
In designing heat exchangers, a designer should not solely focus on the increase of heat transfer, but should also consider the pumping power. Fig. 10 show the effects of inlet water temperature on the pumping power of nano-fluid at various volume fractions of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives and at Reynolds numbers of 500 and 2000. This figure reveals that the increase of inletwater temperature results in the reduction of pumping power. For example, at Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.9% and CNT volume fraction of 1.35%, by raising the inlet water temperature from 308 to 338 K, the pumping power of nano-fluid is reduced by 20.25% and 8.66%, respectively. According to Eq. (11), pumping power is obtained by multiplying pressure loss by nanofluid's volume flow rate. The increase of inlet water temperature leads to the reduction of nano-fluid velocity and thus the reduction of the pressure drop (according to Darcy's equation [35]) and volume flow rate of nano-fluid; which eventually results in the reduction of pumping power. The results also indicate that the pressure loss goes up with the increase of Reynolds number and nanoadditive volume fraction, except at Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.5%. The increase of Reynolds number at a fixed volume fraction of nanoadditives leads to the increase of nanofluid velocity and thus the increase of pressure drop and volume flow rate; and it therefore increases the pumping power of nano-fluid.
The results achieved so far indicate that the augmentation of inlet water temperature results in the enhancement of heat transfer rate and the reduction of pumping power; both of which are desirable. To evaluate the overall effect of inlet water temperature on the hydrodynamic performance of a heat exchanger, the PEC parameter should be investigated. The relevant results have been presented in Fig. 11. It is clear that the rise of inlet water temperature increases the PEC value and improves the hydrodynamic performance of the examined heat exchanger. The findings also indicate that the augmentation of Reynolds number causes the PEC to diminish. In fact, by boosting the Reynolds number, nano-fluid pressure drop intensifies much more than the
heat transfer rate, and this causes the reduction of PEC. Another interesting point demonstrated by Fig. 11 is that in the heat exchanger studied in the present research, the hydrodynamic performance of water is always better than that of the hybrid nano-fluid, except for the Reynolds number of 500, CNT volume fraction of 1.35% and Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.1%. According to the results, in these cases, the PEC values of nanofluid at inlet temperatures of 308 to 338 K are respectively 23.11% to 48.56% higher than those of the water.
To obtain all the results presented so far, thewater Reynolds number is considered fixed at 1000. At the end of this section, the effects of water Reynolds number on the maximum achieved PEC of nano-fluid are evaluated. The findings are depicted in Fig. 12. It is seen that the variations of the PEC of nano-fluid with the water Reynolds number does not have a regular pattern and the highest value belongs to the water Reynolds number of 1000.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this research, we were trying to find out whether, or not, the hydraulic performance of a minichannel hairpin heat exchanger is a function of the temperature difference between the fluids entering the heat exchanger? For this purpose, a horizontal countercurrent hairpin heat exchanger was considered in which a cool nano-fluid circulates inside the tube side and hot water passes through the annular side. The inlet temperature of nano-fluid was assumed as constant, and the inlet temperature of water was changed. The effects of Reynolds number and volume fractions of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives on the obtained results were also investigated. The findings revealed that the rise of inlet water temperature results in the augmentation of heat transfer rate, overall heat transfer coefficient (except at Reynolds number of 500 and at different Fe3O4 volume fractions), heat exchanger effectiveness and PEC; while the pumping power diminish with the augmentation of entering water temperature. The results indicate that the use of nano-fluid in the heat exchanger considered in the present research is not justifiable from the perspective of the first-law of thermodynamics; except at Reynolds number of 500 and Fe3O4 volume fraction of 0.1%, at which the PEC of the heat exchanger is at most 48.56% higher than that of the water. The findings of this research show that in selecting a working fluid for hairpin heat exchangers, a designer should take into consideration the temperature difference between the working fluids.

The findings revealed that the water-CNT/Fe3O4 hybrid nanofluid exhibits pseudoplastic behavior and its viscosity reduces by boosting the shear rate until it reaches a plateau at shear rates higher than 70 s [9].
In addition, as the temperature of nanofluid intensifies, the viscosity of the hybrid nano-fluid reduces [9].
Moreover, the results showed that the thermal conductivity of the hybrid nano-fluid intensifies by boosting the temperature and nanoadditive volume fraction [9].

Using the experimental data, the artificial neural network was utilized to obtain appropriate correlations for viscosity and thermal conductivity of the water-CNT/Fe3O4 hybrid nano-fluid in terms of temperature, volume fraction of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives, and shear rate (for viscosity) [31,32].

Using the experimental data, the artificial neural network was utilized to obtain appropriate correlations for viscosity and thermal conductivity of the water-CNT/Fe3O4 hybrid nano-fluid in terms of temperature, volume fraction of Fe3O4 and CNT nanoadditives, and shear rate (for viscosity) [31,32].

The validation of the numerical method is carried out with the study done by Duangthongsuk and Wongwises [34].
The comparison shows a good agreement between the present results with the findings of Duangthongsuk and Wongwises [34].

The increase of inlet water temperature leads to the reduction of nano-fluid velocity and thus the reduction of the pressure drop (according to Darcy's equation [35]) and volume flow rate of nano-fluid; which eventually results in the reduction of pumping power.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 3 February 2019 Received in revised form 17 May 2019 Accepted 30 May 2019 Available online 04 June 2019 This numerical study aims to focus on the effect of difference between the inlet temperatures ofworking fluids on the hydrothermal characteristics of a counter-current minichannel hairpin heat exchanger. The water flows in the annulus side and the water based hybrid nano-fluid containing Fe3O4 and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) passes through the tube side of heat exchanger. Temperature-dependent thermal conductivity and viscosity are considered for the non-Newtonian hybrid nano-fluid. The effects of Fe3O4 and CNT volume fractions aswell as the Reynolds number on the performance metrics of the heat exchanger are also assessed. The results revealed that the increase of difference between the inlet temperatures ofworkingfluids leads to the augmentation of heat transfer rate, overall heat transfer coefficient (except at Reynolds number of 500), heat exchanger effectiveness and PEC; while the pumping power diminishes with the increase of inlet water temperature. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
